title-group.article-title: The transcriptional regulation of NUPR1 expression by MYC is implicated in the regulation of ferroptosis in human spermatogonial stem cells

abstract.p: Non-obstructive azoospermia (NOA) is a leading cause of male infertility, characterized by impaired spermatogenesis. Recent studies suggest that ferroptosis, an iron-dependent form of cell death, may contribute to testicular dysfunction, however, its role in NOA remains underexplored. In this study, we investigated the roles of NUPR1 and MYC in regulating ferroptosis in human spermatogonial stem cells (SSCs) and evaluated their potential as therapeutic targets for NOA. Single-cell RNA sequencing of testicular tissues from NOA and obstructive azoospermia (OA) patients revealed distinct cellular populations, with UMAP clustering showing a significant reduction in germ cells in NOA samples. High-dimensional weighted gene co-expression network analysis (hdWGCNA) identified two key modules (red and green-yellow) that were associated with spermatogonia. Integrative analysis of scRNA-seq, microarray datasets, and ferroptosis-related genes identified NUPR1 as a key regulatory gene. Immunofluorescence analysis demonstrated NUPR1 co-localization with SSC markers PLZF and UCHL1, and its expression was significantly lower in the testes of NOA patients compared to fertile controls. NUPR1 knockdown in SSCs led to increased ROS levels, lipid peroxidation, and Fe2+ accumulation, along with decreased expression of key ferroptosis markers such as GPX4, NRF2, and KEAP1, cycloheximide chase assays further demonstrated that NUPR1 depletion accelerates the degradation of GPX4 and NRF2, confirming NUPR1’s role in ferroptosis regulation. Moreover, chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) assays showed that MYC binds directly to the NUPR1 promoter, suggesting MYC’s involvement in regulating ferroptosis through NUPR1. These findings identify NUPR1 and MYC as critical regulators of ferroptosis in SSCs, providing novel insights into the molecular mechanisms of NOA and suggesting potential therapeutic strategies targeting ferroptosis for male infertility.

sec.p: The online version contains supplementary material available at 10.1007/s00018-025-05818-2.

list-item.p: NUPR1 and MYC are identified as key regulators of ferroptosis in human spermatogonial stem cells (SSCs).
NUPR1 expression is significantly lower in testicular tissues of NOA patients compared to fertile controls.
NUPR1 knockdown increases ROS levels, lipid peroxidation, and Fe2+ accumulation, confirming its role in ferroptosis regulation.
MYC binds directly to the NUPR1 promoter, contributing to the regulation of ferroptosis in SSCs.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Non-obstructive azoospermia (NOA) is a leading cause of male infertility, characterized by the absence of sperm in the ejaculate due to intrinsic defects in spermatogenesis [1, 2]. NOA affects approximately 1% of the male population and contributes to nearly 10—15% of male infertility cases globally [3]. Despite its clinical significance, the molecular mechanisms underlying NOA remain poorly understood.

In the testis, a variety of cell types, including spermatogonia, Sertoli cells, and Leydig cells, etc. contribute to spermatogenesis through distinct yet equally critical mechanisms [4]. Each cell type plays a specialized role: spermatogonia initiate and maintain the germline [5], Sertoli cells provide structural and biochemical support [6], and Leydig cells regulate the hormonal environment [7]. Dysfunctions within any of these cell populations can disrupt spermatogenesis, contributing to the pathogenesis of NOA. Of particular importance, abnormalities in spermatogonia, the progenitor cells for sperm, have been linked to impaired spermatogenesis, highlighting their crucial role in NOA [8, 9]. In mammals, spermatogonia include undifferentiated spermatogonia (named SSC) and differentiated spermatogonia, which can be identified by markers and morphology, as PLZF, UCHL1 and THY1 are selected as general markers of undifferentiated spermatogonia. However, the long-term culture system of human SSCs in vitro has not been established so far, the fate determination of human SSC and its role in NOA are still need further clarified. We previously established a human SSC line by overexpressing the SV40 large T antigen, which has the phenotype of primary SSC but not differentiation [10], and it can offer a superior model for us to investigate the fate determination and mechanism of human SSCs in vitro [11].

Ferroptosis, an iron-dependent form of regulated cell death driven by lipid peroxidation, has gained attention in recent years for its role in various pathologies [12], including neurodegeneration [13], cancer [14], and organ damage [15]. Unlike apoptosis, ferroptosis is characterized by the accumulation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and depletion of glutathione, leading to oxidative damage in the cell membrane [16]. This form of cell death is particularly relevant in tissues with high oxidative stress [16], such as the testis [17], where germ cells are susceptible to iron-dependent damage [18]. Current research suggests that multiple forms of regulated cell death, including apoptosis and necrosis, are involved in testicular dysfunction [19, 20]. Germ cells, particularly spermatogonia and spermatocytes, are vulnerable to oxidative stress [21], and the dysregulation of ferroptosis could contribute to the observed defects in spermatogenesis [22]. While studies have identified ferroptosis regulators such as GPX4 in other male infertility conditions like asthenozoospermia [23], there is a lack of comprehensive research on ferroptosis mechanisms in NOA. Understanding how ferroptosis is regulated in NOA could provide novel insights into the mechanisms of male infertility and reveal potential therapeutic targets.

In this study, we aim to explore the relationship between ferroptosis and NOA by leveraging scRNA-seq and high-dimensional weighted gene co-expression network analysis (hdWGCNA). Our goal is to identify key regulatory genes and transcription factors involved in ferroptosis and to elucidate their role in human SSC and the relationship with the pathogenesis of NOA. By integrating multiple datasets, including ferroptosis-related genes, scRNA-seq data, and microarray data from NOA patients, we seek to uncover novel molecular mechanisms that contribute to impaired spermatogenesis.

sec.title: Clinical specimen collection and ethical approval
sec.p: This research received ethical clearance from the appropriate institutional review boards of Hunan Normal university (Ethics statement no. 2023171). All patients provided signed informed consent, explicitly allowing the use of their tissue samples for scientific research in compliance with the Declaration of Helsinki.

Due to ethical constraints, obtaining healthy testicular tissue is not feasible. Therefore, testicular tissue samples were obtained from 6 male patients, aged between 23 and 39 years, who underwent microdissection testicular sperm extraction (m-TESE) at the Third Xiangya Hospital of Central South University, as described in our previous studies [11, 24–26]. After collection, the tissues were rinsed three times with phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) supplemented with 4% streptomycin and penicillin. Samples intended for immunohistochemistry were fixed in Bouin’s solution, while those reserved for protein and RNA analysis were rapidly frozen in liquid nitrogen.

OA samples are widely accepted as functional reference tissues in reproductive research. In this study, OA testicular tissues were used as the representative normal spermatogenesis group to evaluate the expression and spatial distribution of target proteins through immunohistochemistry as our previous study [11, 24, 25, 27, 28]. OA specimens used in this study were confirmed to have no signs of active inflammation or fibrotic remodeling based on hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining (Supplementary Fig. 1).

sec.title: Data acquisition
sec.p:
In total, five datasets were collected for this study (Table 1). Two Chinese scRNA-seq datasets (GSE149512 and OEP000778) were downloaded from the GEO and NODE Project, respectively. These datasets were used for the integration of scRNA-seq analysis. Specifically, age is a critical factor that can influence the genetic and cellular characteristics of sperm. Because of the observed higher variability of semen in elderly patients [29], starting from around the age of 40 to 45 years, there is a noticeable decline in sperm quality and male fertility [30]. Studies have shown that men aged 40 years and older have significantly higher rates of sperm DNA fragmentation (index of > 10%) compared to younger men under 40 years [31]. Furthermore, advanced paternal age (≥ 40 years) has been linked to increased DNA fragmentation, chromatin decondensation, sperm aneuploidy rates and associated with poorer outcomes in assisted reproductive techniques [32], we only chose samples aged 18–40 years to reduce age-related variability and obtain a more consistent dataset.Table 1

Additionally, two Bulk-seq datasets (GSE145467 and GSE190752) were obtained from the GEO for external validation. For the analysis of these public datasets, patient consent and ethics committee approval were not necessary. Furthermore, Ferroptosis-related genes were retrieved from FerrDb V2 (http://www.zhounan.org/ferrdb/, updated to 2022/12/31). These genes were categorized into four different function clusters: driver, marker, suppressor, and unclassified. After removing the duplicate genes, 910 ferroptosis-related genes were obtained for further intersection analysis (Table S1).

sec.title: Single-cell RNA sequencing and clustering analysis
sec.p: We analyzed two publicly available single-cell RNA sequencing datasets, GSE149512 and OEP000778, representing testicular tissue from patients with OA and NOA. The data were preprocessed using the Seurat package (version 4.0.6), including filtering for high-quality cells, normalization via SCTransform, and batch correction using the Harmony algorithm. Principal component analysis (PCA) was used for dimensionality reduction, followed by Louvain clustering to identify distinct cell populations. The clusters were visualized using UMAP.

sec.title: Identification of Cluster-Specific marker genes
sec.p: Each identified cluster was annotated using marker genes through differential expression analysis (Table S2, log2 fold-change > 0.25, adjusted p-value < 0.05). These markers allowed the identification of key cell types within the testicular environment, including germline cells (spermatogonia, spermatocytes, spermatids) and somatic cells (Sertoli cells, Leydig cells, peritubular myoid cells, etc.).

sec.title: Identification of differentially expressed genes (DEGs)
sec.p: DEGs were identified from two main data sources: scRNA-seq and independent microarray datasets. First, the DEGs from the combined scRNA-seq datasets (GSE149512 and OEP000778) were calculated. After integrating these two datasets, we utilized the “Limma” R package to compute DEGs with the screening criteria of|log2 fold change (FC)| >0.5 and p < 0.05.

Next, to validate the scRNA-seq results, DEGs were also identified from two microarray datasets: GSE145467 and GSE190752 as our previous methods [33]. These datasets provided an additional layer of validation and were included in the subsequent Venn diagram analysis to identify genes common to the scRNA-seq data, the independent microarray datasets, and ferroptosis-related gene sets.

sec.title: Gene ontology (GO) and Kyoto encyclopedia of genes and genomes (KEGG) enrichment analyses
sec.p: GO and KEGG enrichment analyses were conducted to explore the biological functions and pathways associated with the DEGs in spermatogonia. The ClusterProfiler package was used for functional enrichment, employing the org.Hs.eg.db database to map gene symbols to Entrez gene IDs. For GO enrichment, we focused on the “Biological Process” (BP) ontology, using the Benjamini-Hochberg method for p-value adjustment to control for multiple testing. Similarly, KEGG pathway analysis was performed using the KEGG database with the same p-value adjustment method. Barplots were generated to visualize the top 20 enriched terms for both GO and KEGG pathways.

sec.title: Gene set enrichment analysis (GSEA)
sec.p: To further explore the biological relevance of the DEGs, we performed Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA) using a pre-ranked gene list based on average log2 fold change. The ranked gene list was generated by arranging DEGs in descending order of their fold change. GSEA was performed with the ClusterProfiler package, utilizing the MSigDB Hallmark gene sets to identify enriched pathways. The minimum and maximum gene set sizes were set to 15 and 500, respectively, and adjusted p-values were calculated using the Benjamini-Hochberg method. GSEA results were visualized through ridge plots, barplots, and heatmaps for the top enriched pathways.

sec.title: HdWGCNA reveals key Co-Expressed gene modules associated with spermatogonia
sec.p: To explore gene co-expression patterns within our scRNA-seq data, we utilized hdWGCNA, which is optimized for single-cell data. Unlike traditional WGCNA, hdWGCNA allows for the construction of co-expression networks at cellular resolution, enabling us to capture gene expression patterns within distinct cell populations [34].

We first filtered genes expressed in at least 5% of cells across all samples. Following this, the dataset was transformed into a Metacells object, which aggregates similar cells into pseudo-bulk expression profiles, reducing noise inherent in single-cell data while preserving key expression patterns. For network construction, we selected a soft power threshold of 10, which ensured that the resulting co-expression network adhered to scale-free topology.

The downstream analysis followed the standard hdWGCNA pipeline, identifying distinct gene modules based on co-expression patterns. Each module was assigned a unique color identifier. To link these modules to specific cell types, we correlated module eigengenes (principal components of each module) with known cell-type annotations, focusing on those modules significantly associated with spermatogonia. For full reproducibility, the hdWGCNA pipeline was followed as outlined in the official documentation (available at: https://smorabit.github.io/hdWGCNA, accessed on 07 July 2024).

sec.title: Immunofluorescence and Co-localization analysis
sec.p: Immunofluorescence staining, according to our previous study protocol [11], was performed on human testicular tissue and human SSCs to visualize co-localization of NUPR1 and UCHL1, PLZF or GPX4 (Table S3 and Table S4).

Quantification of co-localization was carried out using ImageJ’s Coloc2 plugin, calculating Pearson’s R value (PRV) and Spearman’s rank correlation value (SRCV) to assess the linear or non-linear correlation of pixel intensities between the two channels, Weak correlation (R < 0.5): This may indicate partial co-localization or random co-expression of the two proteins, Moderate to strong correlation (0.5 ≤ R < 0.7): The two proteins exhibit reasonable spatial overlap but may not be entirely co-localized, High correlation (R ≥ 0.7): Co-localization is very significant, suggesting a close structural or functional relationship between the two proteins.
Manders’ M1 and M2 coefficients were also calculated. Manders’ M1 indicates the fraction of Channel 1 signal overlapping with Channel 2, while M2 reflects the reverse relationship.

sec.title: Cell line and cell culture
sec.p: The human SSC line used in this study was previously established and comprehensively characterized by our group (Prof. Zuping He group) [10]. This cell line has been shown to exhibit key molecular hallmarks of human male germ cells and SSCs [10, 35], Using this SSC model, our group has conducted extensive functional studies, including research on SSC proliferation, xenotransplantation, DNA synthesis, and apoptosis [11, 24–28, 35–49].

For cell culture, the SSC line was maintained in DMEM/F12 medium supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS) (Life Technologies Inc., Grand Island, NY, USA), 100 U/ml penicillin, and 100 µg/ml streptomycin (Life Technologies Inc.) under standard conditions (37 °C in 5% CO2). The cells were passaged every 2–3 days using 0.05% trypsin and 0.53 mM EDTA (Invitrogen) to ensure optimal cell viability and proliferation.

sec.title: SiRNA knockdown of protein and functional assays
sec.p: To investigate the functional role of NUPR1 or MYC in human SSCs, we performed NUPR1 or MYC knockdown using different siRNA constructs targeting NUPR1 or MYC (Genepharma, Suzhou, China), and the sequences are shown in Table S5. Transfection was conducted by Lipofectamine 3000 (Cat No. L3000015, Invitrogen, CA, USA) as the manufacturer’s instruction. Following transfection with these siRNAs, we assessed knockdown efficiency by qRT-PCR and selected the most effective siRNA.

sec.title: Proliferation assay (CCK-8)
sec.p: Cell proliferation was assessed using the CCK-8 assay (NO. ck04, Dojindo). Briefly, human SSCs were treated with siRNAs targeting NUPR1 or control siRNA and cultured for five days. A subset of cells was treated with the ferroptosis inducer (erastin) or ferroptosis inhibitor (ferrostatin-1) to observe the ferroptosis-specific response. Cell viability was measured daily using the CCK-8 reagent according to the manufacturer’s instructions.

sec.title: Fluorescent ROS detection, lipid peroxidation, and ferroorange assays
sec.p: ROS levels were measured in NUPR1 knockdown cells using the ROS-sensitive fluorescent probe (NO. CA1420, Solarbio, Beijing, China), following the manufacturer’s guidelines. Immunofluorescence was performed to visualize ROS levels in siRNA1-treated cells compared with control siRNA. Lipid peroxidation was detected using the lipid peroxidation-specific probe BDP 581/591 C11 (Dojindo, Shanghai, China). Intracellular ferrous ions was detected by FerroOrange (NO. F374, Dojindo, Shanghai, China). Images were captured using a fluorescence microscope (Leica, DM3000, Germany), and fluorescence intensity was quantified using ImageJ.

sec.title: qPCR
sec.p: qPCR was performed as our previous study [11], tissues and cells were lysis by TRIZOL Reagent (Invitrogen, Life Technologies, USA). The nanoDROP one microvolume spectrophotometer (Thermo Fisher) were used for RNA concentration and purity. The cDNAs were produced according to the reverse transcription reagent premix kit (No. AG11706, ACCURATE BIOLOGY) suggestion and protocol. Next, qPCR was performed by the SYBR Green Pro HS Premix qPCR Kits protocol (No. AG11701, ACCURATE BIOLOGY).

The primers were shown in Table S6. ACTB was used as endogenous reference for RNA quantification. The 2^-△△Ct method was used for data analysis. That is, △Ct = Ct (target gene)– Ct (internal reference), △△Ct= △Ct (experimental group) - △Ct (control group).

sec.title: Western blotting
sec.p: Western blotting was performed to evaluate the expression levels of ferroptosis-related proteins, including GPX4, KEAP1, NRF2, and SLC3A2. Protein lysates from siRNA-treated and control cells were extracted, separated by SDS-PAGE, and transferred onto PVDF membranes. Membranes were probed with specific antibodies (Table S3 and Table S4), and signals were detected using enhanced chemiluminescence.

sec.title: Protein stability assay (Cycloheximide Chase)
sec.p: Cells were transfected with control siRNA or NUPR1 siRNA1 for 48 h. Cycloheximide (CHX, 100 µg/mL) was added to inhibit new protein synthesis. Cells were harvested at 0, 6, and 12 h post-CHX treatment. Protein lysates were subjected to Western blotting using antibodies against NUPR1, NRF2, GPX4, and ACTB (loading control). Band intensities were quantified using ImageJ and normalized to ACTB.

sec.title: Transcription factor prediction
sec.p: To predict potential transcription factors that regulate NUPR1, we utilized the TF-Target Finder (TFTF) tool, an R-based integrative platform that bridges multiple predictive models for decoding human transcription factor–target interactions [50], This tool integrates transcription factor binding predictions from databases such as TRANSFAC, CHEA, and ENCODE. The analysis identified MYC as a potential transcriptional regulator of ferroptosis-related genes, which was visualized using a Venn diagram representing the overlap of transcription factors predicted across different models.

sec.title: Validation relationship between NUPR1 and MYC in other databases
sec.p: To verify the co-expression patterns of MYC and NUPR1 in testicular tissue, we employed the GEPIA2 web tool (http://gepia2.cancer-pku.cn) [51], which allows for the analysis of RNA-seq expression data based on the GTEx and TCGA datasets. GEPIA2 was also used to generate scatter plots of log2-transformed TPM values for visualization.

sec.title: ChIP-qPCR assay
sec.p: ChIP assays were performed using the ChIP kit (NO. 26157, Thermo Scientific). Chromatin was cross-linked, sonicated, and immunoprecipitated using anti-MYC antibody. The DNA-protein complexes were reverse cross-linked, and the resulting DNA was amplified using qPCR with primers targeting the NUPR1 promoter (Table S7). Input% method was used to calculate IP efficiency, Input% = 2%×2 (CT (2%Input)– CT(MYC)).

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Sigmaplot 13.0 (Systat Software lnc.) was used to analyze the data. An t-test was performed for the assessment of hub gene differential expression in the different data sets. The correlation analysis was performed using Pearson analysis. Data are shown as means ± standard deviation. GO and KEGG enrichment analyses were assessed using the Fisher’s exact test. To compare the PCR and Western Blot relative expression between OA and control tissues, Student’s t-test was used to analysis normally distributed variables, and the Mann-Whitney rank sum test was applied analyze non-normally distributed variables. For all assessments, P < 0.05 was defined as statistically significant.

sec.title: Single-cell clustering reveals testicular cell populations and differences between OA and NOA
sec.p:
UMAP clustering revealed 14 distinct testicular cell populations, including germline cells such as spermatogonia, spermatocytes, and spermatids, as well as somatic support cells like Sertoli cells, Leydig cells, and peritubular myoid cells (Fig. 1A, Table S2). These clusters were broadly divided into two major groups: germline cells responsible for spermatogenesis and somatic microenvironment cells that provide structural and biochemical support. A comparison of absolute cell counts between OA (n = 31566) and NOA (n = 9856) samples (Fig. 1B) confirms that NOA patients have a substantially reduced total number of spermatogenic cells, although the relative percentages of certain clusters (e.g., spermatocytes and spermatids) appear elevated in NOA due to the smaller dataset, their absolute counts remain far lower than in OA. UMAP projections (Fig. 1C) highlighted the reduced representation of spermatogenic cells in NOA, whereas OA samples displayed a more even distribution of germline cells across the clusters.Fig. 1
UMAP clustering and proportion analysis of testicular cells in OA and NOA patients. (A) UMAP plot showing distinct clustering of testicular cells, including spermatogonia, spermatocytes, spermatids, and somatic support cells (Sertoli cells, Leydig cells, etc.). (B) Bar plot illustrating the proportions of different cell types in OA and NOA patients. (C) UMAP projections for OA and NOA samples demonstrate a reduction in spermatogenic cells in NOA patients. (D) Dot plot displaying the expression levels of key marker genes across the identified cell clusters. The size of the dots represents the percentage of cells expressing each gene, while the color indicates the average expression level

The expression of specific marker genes based on Table S2 was visualized across the clusters in Fig. 1D. The dot size represents the proportion of cells expressing each marker gene, and the color intensity indicates the average expression level within each cluster, showing distinct expression patterns for both germline and somatic cells. The distribution of individual marker genes is further shown in Supplementary Fig. 2.

The overlap in marker gene expression observed across germline cells (spermatogonia, spermatocytes, and spermatids) reflects the biological continuity and dynamic gene expression changes during the differentiation process. This observation further validates the biological rationale of our clustering. Specifically, for spermatogonia, we utilized recently reported markers such as ID4 [52, 53], KIT [52, 54–56], and SMS [2, 54] to distinguish this cell population.

This provides a comprehensive map of testicular cell populations that will support subsequent functional analyses. Supplementary Fig. 3 presents the functional enrichment analysis results, showing biological processes related to cell cycle regulation, DNA replication, and chromosomal segregation in germline cells, providing a foundation for understanding the disruptions in spermatogenesis observed in NOA patients.

sec.title: HdWGCNA reveals key Co-Expressed gene modules associated with spermatogonia
sec.p:
hdWGCNA identified a total of 14 co-expressed gene modules, each represented by a distinct color (Fig. 2A and B). We visualized the expression patterns of the 14 gene co-expression modules identified by hdWGCNA (Fig. 2C). Each module is represented by a unique color, Dot size Represents the proportion of cells within each cell type expressing genes from a specific module. Color intensity Indicates the average expression level of the genes in the module. Given that our study focuses on spermatogonia-related biological changes, we found that red and green-yellow modules exhibit notable expression patterns within the spermatogonia cluster (Fig. 2C), indicating their potential involvement in spermatogenesis. The top hub genes in the red module included RPL28, RPL18, and RPS15, while the greenyellow module was enriched with genes such as ATOX1, COX6C, and TIMM8B (Fig. 2D), subsequently, we extracted the genes from the red and green-yellow modules as hdWGCNA module genes for further intersection analysis.Fig. 2
hdWGCNA reveals co-expressed gene modules associated with spermatogonia. (A) Scale-free topology and connectivity measures used to determine the soft-thresholding power for the construction of the co-expression network. A soft threshold of 10 was chosen. (B) Hierarchical clustering dendrogram of genes, with different colors representing the modules identified by hdWGCNA. (C) Dot plot showing the expression of the identified gene modules across different cell types. The red and green-yellow modules were highly expressed in spermatogonia. (D) Bar plots showing the module membership (kME) of the top hub genes in the red and green-yellow modules

sec.title: NUPR1 as a key regulator in NOA and ferroptosis pathways
sec.p:
To identify potential key regulators linking NOA and ferroptosis pathways, we performed a multi-layered intersection analysis combining several datasets: DEGs from scRNA-seq analysis (based on Fold Change > 1.5 and p-value < 0.05), genes from hdWGCNA gene modules (red and green-yellow modules) associated with spermatogonia, ferroptosis-related genes curated from the FerrDb database V2, and DEGs of two independent microarray datasets (GSE145467 and GSE190752). This comprehensive analysis resulted in a single intersecting gene, NUPR1, as shown in the Venn diagram (Fig. 3A). The identification of NUPR1 as the sole overlapping gene highlights its potential as a critical regulator of ferroptosis and its involvement in NOA pathogenesis, particularly within the spermatogonia population. Figures 3B-D illustrate NUPR1’s significant downregulation across different datasets, demonstrating its consistent reduction in NOA tissues compared to OA controls (P < 0.0001, P < 0.05, and P < 0.01). We collected OA and NOA patient samples to verify the results of datasets. We found the reduced expression of NUPR1 in NOA testis, specifically in those with spermatogonia maturation arrest (SPG) and spermatocyte maturation arrest (SPC) (Fig. 3I-K), providing evidence of NUPR1’s downregulation in NOA subtypes compared to OA patients. These results emphasize NUPR1’s relevance in the context of testicular dysfunction in NOA.Fig. 3
NUPR1 is identified as a key intersecting gene associated with NOA and ferroptosis. (A) Venn diagram illustrating the intersection of differentially expressed genes from single-cell sequencing, hdWGCNA modules, microarray datasets, and ferroptosis-related gene sets, identifying NUPR1 as the sole common intersecting gene. (B-D) NUPR1 expression in different datasets (GSE145467, GSE190752, and scRNA-seq) is significantly reduced in NOA patients compared to OA controls. (E) Immunofluorescence staining showing the co-localization of NUPR1 (green) with UCHL1 (red) in normal human spermatogenesis testicular tissues. Co-localization analysis was performed using ImageJ Coloc2. Scale bars represent 25 μm. (F-G) Immunofluorescence showing high expression of NUPR1 in SSCs marked by PLZF and UCHL1. Co-localization analysis was performed using ImageJ Coloc2. Scale bars represent 25 μm. (H) Co-localization of NUPR1 and GPX4 in cultured human SSC. Co-localization analysis was performed using ImageJ Coloc2. Scale bars represent 25 μm. (I-K) PCR (I) and Western blot (J-K) analysis showing significantly reduced NUPR1 expression in clinical NOA patient subgroups (4 NOA patients, SPG, SPC) compared to OA patients (2 OA patients, *P < 0.05, **P < 0.01)

As shown in our previous analysis, NUPR1 is mainly expressed in spermatogonia. To investigate whether the association of NUPR1 with NOA is due to its involvement in the regulation of ferroptosis in spermatogonia, we performed immunofluorescence analysis in normal human spermatogenesis testicular tissues. Co-localization of NUPR1 with UCHL1, a well-known spermatogonia marker, was observed (Fig. 3E). Quantitative analysis using ImageJ’s Coloc2 plugin provided the following metrics: Pearson’s R = 0.52 and Spearman’s rank correlation coefficient = 0.61, indicating a moderate linear and rank-based correlation and suggesting partial co-localization. Manders’ M1 = 0.99 demonstrated that nearly all UCHL1-positive signals overlapped with NUPR1, while Manders’ M2 = 0.59 highlighted that NUPR1 is also expressed in other testicular cell types, suggesting broader functional roles. These results confirm that NUPR1 is significantly expressed in spermatogonia and provide evidence for its presence in other testicular cell populations, further supporting its potential functional versatility in the testis.

In our cultured human SSCs, NUPR1 demonstrated high co-localization with the SSC markers PLZF and UCHL1 (Fig. 3F and G). Quantification yielded the following results: For PLZF, Pearson’s R = 0.77 and Spearman’s = 0.86, indicating a strong correlation, both linear and rank-based. Manders’ M1 = 0.99, showing that PLZF-positive signals almost completely overlapped with NUPR1, while Manders’ M2 = 1.00 confirmed that NUPR1 signals were highly restricted to PLZF-positive regions. For UCHL1, Pearson’s R = 0.82 and Spearman’s = 0.88 demonstrated very strong co-localization. Manders’ M1 = 0.98 indicated that nearly all UCHL1 signals co-expressed with NUPR1, and Manders’ M2 = 0.94 showed that most NUPR1 signals overlapped with UCHL1-positive regions. These results validate NUPR1’s critical role in maintaining SSC identity through its co-localization with established SSC markers.

To explore NUPR1’s potential involvement in ferroptosis regulation, we analyzed its co-localization with GPX4, a key ferroptosis regulator, in cultured human SSCs (Fig. 3H). Quantitative analysis using ImageJ’s Coloc2 plugin showed Pearson’s R = 0.78 and Spearman’s rank correlation coefficient = 0.88, indicating a strong spatial correlation. Manders’ M1 = 1.00 demonstrated that all GPX4-positive signals overlapped with NUPR1, while Manders’ M2 = 1.00 confirmed that all NUPR1 signals overlapped with GPX4-positive regions. These findings provide strong evidence that NUPR1 may regulate ferroptosis in SSCs through its close association with GPX4, particularly under conditions of oxidative stress.

sec.title: NUPR1 knockdown inhibits SSC proliferation and increases ferroptosis sensitivity
sec.p: To verify the efficiency of NUPR1 knockdown, three different siRNA constructs targeting NUPR1 (siRNA1, siRNA2, and siRNA3) were tested. qPCR analysis revealed that NUPR1 expression was significantly reduced by siRNA1 and siRNA3 compared to the control siRNA group, with siRNA1 showing the most effective knockdown (Supplementary Fig. 4A, P < 0.01). Western blotting further confirmed the decrease in NUPR1 protein levels across all siRNA groups (Supplementary Fig. 4B), with quantification showing a significant reduction in protein levels for siRNA1 (Supplementary Fig. 4C). The results suggest that siRNA1 provides the most robust knockdown at both the mRNA and protein levels.

NUPR1 knockdown significantly inhibited the proliferation of human SSCs, as shown in the CCK-8 assay (Fig. 4A). This inhibition became apparent from day 3 post-transfection of NUPR1 siRNAs and persisted through day 5. The rescue of human SSCs proliferation upon co-treatment with ferrostatin-1, as shown in the CCK-8 assay (Fig. 4B), further highlights the ferroptosis-dependent nature of the cell death induced by NUPR1 knockdown. Western blot analysis revealed that NUPR1 knockdown led to a marked reduction in ferroptosis-related markers, including GPX4, KEAP1, NRF2, and SLC3A2 (Fig. 4C-G). As with the previous efficiency assays, the siRNA1 group likewise showed the strongest regulatory effect on the other proteins.Fig. 4
NUPR1 knockdown affects cell proliferation, ROS levels, and ferroptosis in human SSCs. (A) CCK-8 assay was performed to assess cell proliferation following NUPR1 knockdown with siRNA1, siRNA2, and siRNA3 in human SSCs (*P < 0.05). (B) Cells were treated with the ferroptosis inducer erastin and the ferroptosis inhibitor ferrostatin-1. Erastin treatment further inhibited proliferation, while ferrostatin-1 rescued the effect (*P < 0.05, **P < 0.01). (C) Western blot analysis was used to evaluate the expression levels of ferroptosis-related markers GPX4, KEAP1, NRF2, and SLC3A2 after NUPR1 knockdown. ACTB (β-actin) was used as a loading control. (D-G) Quantification of western blot data, indicating protein expression levels of GPX4, KEAP1, NRF2, and SLC3A2 normalized to ACTB. Statistically significant differences compared to control are indicated (*P < 0.05, **P < 0.01). (H) FerroOrange staining was performed to measure intracellular Fe²⁺ levels. Increased fluorescence intensity was observed in NUPR1 knockdown cells, indicating elevated iron levels (P < 0.0001). (I) Lipid peroxidation was assessed using a lipid peroxidation probe. Increased lipid peroxidation was observed in NUPR1 knockdown cells (P < 0.01). (J) Immunofluorescence staining was used to detect reactive oxygen species (ROS) levels in NUPR1 knockdown cells, showing a significant increase (P < 0.0001)

Additionally, intracellular Fe2+ levels, detected via FerroOrange staining, were significantly increased in NUPR1 knockdown cells, as confirmed by fluorescence intensity quantification (P < 0.0001) (Fig. 4H). Lipid peroxidation level was increased in NUPR1 knockdown cells, measured by Lipid Peroxidation Probe peroxide level (Fig. 4I). Similarly, ROS levels were significantly elevated after NUPR1 knockdown (Fig. 4J). These results proved the inhibition of NUPR1 on ferroptosis in human SSCs.

To further investigate the mechanism underlying the observed downregulation of GPX4 and NRF2 proteins, we performed CHX chase assays to assess their stability, NUPR1 knockdown markedly accelerated the degradation of both NRF2 (Supplementary Fig. 5B) and GPX4 (Supplementary Fig. 5C) in SSCs upon CHX treatment. These findings indicate that NUPR1 functions as a post-translational stabilizer of ferroptosis-protective proteins, helping to preserve intracellular antioxidant capacity in human SSCs.

sec.title: MYC regulates NUPR1 and ferroptosis pathways
sec.p:
Through integrative transcription factor prediction analysis using the TF-Target Finder tool [50], MYC was identified as a potential transcriptional regulator of NUPR1. A Venn diagram from multiple datasets, including CHEA and TF-target databases, highlighted MYC as an overlapping transcription factor of interest (Fig. 5A). Additionally, correlation analysis using the GEPIA2 platform showed a strong positive correlation between MYC and NUPR1 expression in testicular tissues (Fig. 5B, R = 0.72, p-value < 0.05), suggesting a co-regulatory relationship in NOA.Fig. 5
MYC regulates NUPR1 and ferroptosis pathways. (A)Venn diagram illustrating the identification of MYC as a transcriptional regulator of NUPR1 and ferroptosis-related genes based on integrative analysis of multiple transcription factor databases. (B) Correlation analysis using the GEPIA2 web tool showing a significant positive correlation between MYC and NUPR1 expression in testicular tissues (R = 0.72, P < 0.05). (C) Quantitative reverse transcription PCR (qRT-PCR) was performed to measure MYC mRNA expression following MYC knockdown. Data are normalized to ACTB and shown relative to control (P < 0.05, **P < 0.01). (D) Western blot analysis showing the effects of MYC knockdown on the expression levels of MYC, NUPR1, and GPX4 proteins in human SSCs. ACTB (β-actin) served as the loading control. (E-G) Quantification of western blot data showing relative expression levels of MYC, GPX4, and NUPR1 after MYC knockdown. Statistical significance is indicated (*P < 0.05, **P < 0.01). (H) Quantitative reverse transcription PCR (qRT-PCR) was performed to measure NUPR1 mRNA expression following MYC knockdown. Data are normalized to ACTB and shown relative to control (P < 0.05). (I) Chromatin immunoprecipitation followed by quantitative PCR (ChIP-qPCR) was used to confirm MYC binding to predicted NUPR1 promoter sites. Data are presented as input-normalized enrichment of MYC binding (*P < 0.05). (J) Co-localization of NUPR1 and MYC in cultured human SSC. Co-localization analysis was performed using ImageJ Coloc2. Scale bars represent 25 μm

We then knocked down the expression level of MYC to demonstrate the regulation of MYC on NUPR1 expression and ferroptosis of human SSCs. Western blotting analysis revealed that MYC knockdown via siRNAs resulted in a significant reduction in NUPR1, GPX4 (Fig. 5D). Quantification of these results further confirmed these reductions, with statistical significance observed in MYC siRNA2, where the greatest knockdown effect was noted (Figs. 5E-G). Notably, the expression patterns of NUPR1 and GPX4 under different MYC knockdown conditions were highly consistent, with MYC siRNA2 showing the greatest knockdown effect, accompanied by the most significant reductions in NUPR1 and GPX4 levels.

Furthermore, the binding sites of MYC to NUPR1 was predicted via JASPAR (JASPAR - A database of transcription factor binding profiles (elixir.no)), and ChIP-qPCR assays demonstrated that MYC directly binds to the promoter region of NUPR1, with significant enrichment seen across three predicted binding sites on the NUPR1 promoter region (Fig. 5I). These findings support the role of MYC in regulating ferroptosis pathways via its transcriptional control over NUPR1.

In our cultured human SSCs, MYC demonstrated high co-localization with NUPR1 (Fig. 5J). Quantification yielded the following results: Pearson’s R = 0.86 and Spearman’s = 0.82, indicating a strong correlation, both linear and rank-based. Manders’ M1 = 1.00 showed that MYC-positive signals completely overlapped with NUPR1, while Manders’ M2 = 1.00 confirmed that NUPR1 signals were entirely restricted to MYC-positive regions. These results strongly support a close spatial relationship between MYC and NUPR1, reinforcing the potential regulatory role of MYC in modulating NUPR1 expression and its associated pathways in SSCs.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study investigates the molecular mechanisms underlying NOA, a leading cause of male infertility characterized by the absence of sperm in the ejaculate due to intrinsic defects in spermatogenesis. A major challenge in studying NOA is its complexity, as it involves multiple cell types in the testis, including germline and somatic cells [2]. The lack of effective knowledge to identify specific cell populations and the interplay of various cell death mechanisms, such as apoptosis and necrosis, further complicates our understanding of NOA pathogenesis. Recent reviews emphasize the importance of cell-type-specific analyses to better understand the cellular dysfunctions that lead to NOA [8].

Among the testicular cell types, SSCs are particularly important as they represent the progenitor cells for spermatogenesis, making them crucial for maintaining the germline and ensuring sperm production [57]. Ferroptosis, an iron-dependent form of cell death, has emerged as a crucial process implicated in a range of pathological conditions, including reproductive dysfunction [58, 59]. However, its specific role in SSCs and NOA has remained largely unexplored until now.

To address these challenges, our scRNA-seq delineates distinct testicular cell populations, including germline cells (spermatogonia, spermatocytes, and spermatids) and somatic cells (Sertoli and Leydig cells). This spatial separation between germline and somatic cells mirrors the functional organization of the testis, where spermatogenesis takes place in the seminiferous epithelium, which is composed of germ and Sertoli cells with the Sertoli cell serving as the “mother” or the “nursery” cell that supports and nourishes germ cells at different stages of their development [60, 61]. We observed a general reduction in the number of testicular cells across all cell populations in NOA patients compared to OA patients. This finding is consistent with previous research, which has demonstrated that NOA is characterized by widespread germline and somatic cell dysfunction, leading to a lower count of not only spermatogenic cells but also supporting cells like Sertoli and Leydig cells [62]. Spermatogonia depletion is strongly linked to increased cell death mechanisms [63]. Previous studies have shown that in NOA, the depletion of spermatogonia is one of the primary drivers of spermatogenic failure. This loss of spermatogonia has been attributed to increased oxidative stress and the activation of cell death pathways such as apoptosis, which disrupt the ability of the testis to produce sperm [64, 65].

Through GO, KEGG, and GSEA analyses, we identified several key pathways within the spermatogonia cluster that are relevant to ferroptosis. GO analysis highlighted pathways such as DNA replication, cell cycle regulation, and chromosomal segregation, which are crucial for spermatogonia proliferation and maintenance [66–68]. Moreover, KEGG analysis pointed to oxidative stress and apoptosis-related pathways, strongly suggesting that oxidative stress-induced lipid peroxidation in ferroptosis plays a pivotal role in the dysfunction of spermatogonia [69]. The GSEA analysis further reinforced this by showing enrichment in cellular redox homeostasis and iron metabolism, all core elements of ferroptosis [12, 18]. These pathway analyses are consistent with our next ferroptosis-related experimental findings.

Using hdWGCNA, we identified the red and green-yellow modules as co-expressed gene modules associated with spermatogonia, integrative analysis further revealed NUPR1 as a key intersecting gene, combining differential expression data from single-cell RNA sequencing, hdWGCNA modules, ferroptosis-related gene sets and different independent databased. Co-localization of NUPR1 with SSC markers UCHL1 and PLZF indicates that NUPR1 may function in human SSCs, possibly contributing to regulatory mechanisms governing testicular health.

The strong correlation between NUPR1 and GPX4 in cultured human SSC supports the hypothesis that NUPR1 plays a significant role in regulating ferroptosis. In clinical samples, the marked reduction of NUPR1 expression in SPG and SPC NOA subtypes suggests that NUPR1’s loss may be linked to germ cell arrest and infertility. These findings provide a compelling rationale for further investigation into NUPR1 as a potential therapeutic target for preserving SSC function and preventing ferroptosis-induced cell death in NOA.

Next, to further confirm the function of NUPR1 in ferroptosis, we found NUPR1 knockdown not only inhibits human SSC proliferation but also significantly increases the cells’ sensitivity to ferroptosis. This sensitivity is marked by increased ROS levels, lipid peroxidation, and iron accumulation, all of which are hallmarks of ferroptosis. This findings support the hypothesis that NUPR1 functions as a ferroptosis suppressor by limiting iron accumulation, oxidative stress and stabilizing key antioxidant proteins. NUPR1 knockdown not only reduced GPX4, KEAP1, and NRF2 levels but also accelerated GPX4/NRF2 degradation in CHX chase assays, further highlights the central role of NUPR1 in maintaining cellular redox balance and protecting human SSC from ferroptosis-induced cell death.

Moreover, MYC was identified as a transcriptional regulator of NUPR1 and ferroptosis-related genes, this prediction relationship was confirmed through further validation in human testicular tissues using GEPIA2. The correlation observed between MYC and NUPR1 supports their potential TFs-regulation relationship. Later ChIP analysis further established MYC’s binding to the NUPR1 promoter, providing a mechanistic basis for how MYC regulates ferroptosis in human SSCs. MYC knockdown experiments demonstrated that reducing MYC expression decreased NUPR1 levels, leading to alterations in ferroptosis-related gene expression, such as GPX4. Moreover, the co-localization of MYC and NUPR1 in cultured SSCs further strengthens the evidence that MYC acts as a transcriptional regulator of NUPR1. The complete overlap in fluorescence signals suggests that MYC and NUPR1 are closely associated at the subcellular level, potentially within specific chromatin or regulatory complexes. These results, combined with ChIP data, highlight MYC’s pivotal role in regulating NUPR1 expression and its downstream effects on ferroptosis pathways, particularly in the context of spermatogonia function and oxidative stress responses.

This finding aligns with the results from Fig. 4, where direct knockdown of NUPR1 led to a marked reduction in GPX4 expression. The consistent trends observed in these two independent experimental approaches provide further evidence supporting the regulatory axis of MYC-NUPR1-GPX4 in ferroptosis pathways. These results reinforce the notion that NUPR1 plays a central role in linking MYC signaling to ferroptosis regulation in human SSCs.

These data emphasize MYC’s key role in maintaining oxidative homeostasis in SSCs by controlling ferroptosis sensitivity. Interestingly, recent research has specifically demonstrated that c-MYC can transcriptionally activate ACSL4, thereby promoting ferroptosis in hepatocytes [70], our findings extend this role to the regulation of ferroptosis in spermatogonia, with potential therapeutic implications.

Similarly to cell MYC-involved apoptosis, this dual role of MYC in regulating ferroptosis might be cell-type-specific, MYC is known to exert pro-apoptotic effects in most normal cells, particularly in those lacking growth factors [71]. However, in rapidly proliferating cells with high growth potential, such as tumor cells, MYC not only exhibits anti-apoptotic effects [71–74], but also confers resistance to ferroptosis [75–78] We hypothesize that compared to normal cells, the similarities between SSCs and tumor cells—both cell types exhibit high proliferative activity and share key markers, such as PLZF (promyelocytic leukemia zinc finger protein), and SOX2, which are characteristic of stem cells [79–83]—may influence their sensitivity to regulated cell death pathways such as ferroptosis. Additionally, MYC family proteins have been implicated in spermatogenesis and male germ cell tumors, where they regulate metabolic processes and suppress apoptotic pathways [84]. Our findings are consistent with these roles, highlighting MYC’s potential to modulate cell death pathways, including both apoptosis and ferroptosis, in reproductive cells. This suggests that MYC’s regulatory functions are conserved across different contexts, including spermatogenesis and tumorigenesis, where it fine-tunes the balance between cell survival and death based on the cell’s metabolic and proliferative state.

In conclusion, our study identifies NUPR1 and MYC as critical regulators of human SSCs function and ferroptosis in NOA at first time. These findings provide a foundation for further investigation into the molecular mechanisms of NOA and highlight the potential of targeting ferroptosis as a therapeutic strategy. Future studies should explore the broader implications of ferroptosis in testicular diseases and its possible role in other forms of male infertility.

notes.title: Generative AI and AI-assisted technologies in the writing process
notes.p: During the preparation of this work, we used OpenAI’s ChatGPT-4 solely as an academic English editor. Prompts were structured as follows:

“You are an academic English editor. I am a non-native English–speaking researcher submitting my manuscript draft and notes. Do not alter any of the scientific logic, data interpretation, or conclusions. Please proofread the text for grammar, syntax, and word choice, and adjust the wording and sentence structure to conform to formal academic English. Return the fully edited version with trackable changes.”

No part of the prompts requested result interpretation or content generation beyond language polishing. After using this tool/service, the authors reviewed and edited the content as needed and takes full responsibility for the content of the published article.
